overview_of_class:
The fundamental purpose of this course is the expanding of our students' horizons -
especially through movies. The students will be introduced to the Latin-American culture
through this engaging media; and help the students in the class to learn about events in
specific cultures which have contributed to the panorama of the Latin-American's world
community - for instance, the Mexican revolution, life in Cuba during the dictatorship of
Castro, Chile in the 1970's, and so on. In addition to these memorable and salient references
to contemporary history, the films will also teach students about the daily life of their
protagonists with respect to food and meals, family and community traditions, the raising and
education of children, etc. Such information provides a means for the student to grow in
mindfulness of the quotidian lives of other peoples, as well as offering enjoyment to the
whole class through sharing the viewing of much that is beautiful, uplifting, and thought provoking.
Participating in the course will enhance critical thinking because students will
learn how to evaluate and compare real events as recorded and portrayed in different movies.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
After taking this course, students should be able to show they can:

  • Examine, critically, the meanings of customs/habits among different Hispanic cultures.

  • Explore the ways in which geographical, cultural, political, and economic forces interact
    to influence the culture of the region.

  • Engage in debates with their classmates concerning the meaning and importance of some
    habits, traditions, or customs as a powerful symbol of social and cultural meanings.

  • Contribute meaningfully to class discussion by identifying their own questions about the
    movies, by articulating their insights about the movies and readings, and by respectfully
    responding to others comments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
The course will include introductory lectures; class discussions related to the movie
scheduled for that class day, readings, and student presentations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The participation grade is based on the student's watching the movie [before each class] and
writing a synopsis/critique of the movie addressing the questions posted for that class day. In
class, the students will sit in groups of three and read materials related to the movie they
watched. This part of the evaluation will count toward 60% of the final grade. The Final
Project will be divided in two parts: an oral presentation, and a written essay. I will provide a
guide for the students to follow. This final Project will be worth 40% of the final grade.
Further details will be distributed in class and posted on CMS.

overview_of_class: In many ways, the subject of the environment is a focal point for any number of disciplines, both in the liberal arts and hard sciences, to come together in the great clearing house we call "the humanities". This course will offer a balanced approach to the growth and change in literature devoted to the subject of the environment, touching briefly on 19th century foundations (the assigned writers in the reader discussing Muir, Ruskin, Emerson, Thoreau) and moving quickly to the explosion of what may be a genre of literature unto its own. We will consider contributions from poetry, drama, fiction, and nonfiction, documentary, advocacy journalism, polemic. We will consider science and philosophy, art and religion, history and politics, all in the way they come to this huge and pressing subject. In order to further focus a very rich area of literature and art, we will focus especially on the idea of "Living in Nature": why we want to, what it means, and what are the consequences. We will consider specifically Into the Wild (Krakauer), Derzu the Trapper (Arseniev), Thoreau's Walden, Giono's The Man who Planted Trees, Janet Kauffman's Rot, Junichiro Tanizaki's In Praise of Shadows, and Werner Herzog's documentary "Grizzly Man". We will take time to discuss, under this subtopic, hunting and literature (with works by Edward Abbey, Joy Williams, James Swan, and possibly Ted Nugent).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
After taking this course, students should be able to show they can:

  • Through the topic of environment, we will invite considerations of literature through the lenses of science and art; of economics, psychology/biology, history, anthropology, religion, public policy and sociology.

  • Through lecture, discussion, short and long papers, and student presentations, this multidisciplinary course will provide both a survey and a focus on learning how to perform a close reading of poetry and prose.

  • Because I am a lecturer in the English Major in Writing, there will be an emphasis on good writing, and improving student writing.

  • Continue to examine the emerging literature on the environment, and the new environmental criticism movement.

  • Student will be taken for a field trip to the vertical farm called "The Plant", situated near the location of Lewis's The Jungle.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: One presentation, two short papers (2-3 pages with prompts assigned in class, and one long final term paper, 7-10 pages in length. Weekly quizzes (nothing tricky, but to make sure students do the reading). At the end of the term, students will be asked to offer a fifteen-minute presentation on material approved by the instructor. Daily journal entries, offering "talking points" will be collected every two weeks.

overview_of_class:
In this class, we will view and discuss contemporary German films
since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Using the fascinating global
city Berlin as a focal point and as a mirror for German history in the
20th and 21st century, we will analyze films dealing with German
Reunification (Goodbye Lenin, Lives of Others, Barbara) and Post-
Reunification (Victoria, Kaddish for a Friend), while also discussing
approaches to film analysis.
As the Area VI requirement states, "the course will help
[students] understand how the attitudes, ideas, and values of
individuals, groups, societies, or cultures are represented in their
literature, arts, and other creative activities." In particular, we will
trace how perspectives regarding East and West and regarding
walls and borders are represented in German films and how these
perspectives have changed in the last 25 years, both on a national
as well as transnational level.
In order to explore German-American connections on site,
we will include an excursion to the Berlin Wall memorial in Lincoln
Square at the Western El Stop along with a visit to additional sites in
Lincoln Square's Germantown and including an ethnic culinary
experience in a German restaurant. During the second part of the
course, we plan another excursion to explore German-influenced
architecture in Chicago with references to the films that we see
and, depending on availability, we may plan a trip to the European
film festival to watch a current German film.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
After taking this course, students should be able to show they can:

  • Be familiar with and able to use key concepts, language, and approaches related to film analysis.

  • Acquire knowledge and understanding regarding the history of German film, including movements, trends, directors, and actors and actresses.

  • Be familiar with German history related to the Berlin Wall, reunification, and the current refugee crisis.

  • Be able to discuss, critically evaluate, and interpret films involving German history and culture.

  • Identify and learn to research German-American connections in Chicago.

  • Critically evaluate the presence of national and transnational concerns in German cinema at a formal as well as thematic level.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation, short homework assignments, quizzes, essays, research project and presentation.
